Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Bringing Innovative Ionic Solutions to the Ultracapacitor Market
Award.AbstractNarration:
The team has developed a patent pending electrolyte chemistry that is believed to have the potential to improve the performance of ultracapacitors that are an important, but underutilized component in energy storage solutions. To date, the adoption of ultracapacitors has been limited due to inadequate energy storage performance and high costs. However, a number of technological breakthroughs have made the
ultracapacitor commercially viable. Applications are currently dominated by the automotive and electronic industries with large potential in solar and wind energy storage and industrial applications. The demand for ultracapacitor in automotive start-up systems is projected to be the primary source of growth over the next decade. As the ultracapacitor market grows and more firms enter, it will become increasingly competitive. These companies will need to provide technically superior products. The adoption of the proposed patent pending electrolyte will allow companies to easily improve performance with little engineering effort.

The proposed electrolyte has demonstrated promising improvements in proof-of-concept testing that were validated by an independent laboratory. The proposed electrolyte was compared with the current industry standard and showed 19% higher capacitance and 15% high breakdown potential translating into more energy storage, and wider temperature and voltage ranges. Longevity testing has shown that the proposed technology has a lifetime of approximately 100,000 cycles, and these improvements could translate into new applications for electrochemical double layer capacitors (EDLC). The goal of this proposal is to show that the proposed electrolye can be smoothly integrated into existing and future ultracapacitor devices in a "plug and play" fashion. The team will use the I-Corps training to develop a commercial-scale prototype to demonstrate the technology to potential customers and partners and develop a commercialization plan to bring the product to market.

Institution.Name: SUNY at Albany
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Team Eonix participated in the NSF Innovation Program in summer 2014 with the following team: Entrepreneurial Lead Don Derosa, Principal Investigator, Prof. Laura Schultz, and Business Mentor Dr. Fernando Gomez-Baquero.

Eonix developed an electrolyte chemistry that can be used for ultra-capacitors. Ultra-capacitors are energy storage devices that can charge and discharge energy very quickly. The electrolyte is one of the three main components of an ultra-capacitor and Eonix’ technology enables increased energy storage, a wider temperature operation range, and lower costs.

In this project Eonix devised a go to market strategy for their technology. Originally, the team thought the automotive industry would be an ideal first customer for the enhanced ultra-capacitors. The automotive industry is facing considerable regulatory and market pressure to improve the fuel efficiency of their vehicles. Ultra-capacitors are ideal for conserving energy when cars start and stop in micro and full hybrid systems.  Interviews with dozens of automotive engineers and product development teams revealed that the product market fit was not idea. Engineers do not understand how to incorporate ultra-capacitors, which have a linearly decreasing voltage during discharge, in place of batteries, which has a constant voltage during discharge. Another key barrier was the automotive industry’s well-defined chain of suppliers and rigorous, multi-year, screening processes that make it difficult for new firms to enter the supply chain. These obstacles are too overwhelming for current ultra-capacitor manufacturers to overcome given their size and available resources and it is unlikely that ultra-capacitors will be adopted in the automotive industry on the large scale in the near term.

Eonix identified and interviewed over two dozen ultra-capacitor manufacturers. The four largest ultra-capacitor companies are too risk adverse to purchase a key input from an early stage company. Emerging companies had a far shorter adoption cycle and were eager to implement new technologies that could provide any advantage to capture more market share. Eonix identified three product specifications important to these firms. (1)An electrolyte must enable higher voltage operation enabling a reduction in both the size and the cost of ultra-capacitors. (2)A lower electrical series resistance (ESR) was also a concern for ionic liquid based electrolytes. (3) Companies in Japan and Europe strongly desired an electrolyte without the solvent acetonitrile due to its potentially toxic properties. These smaller firms have a limited market share and questionable capital availability. Despite these limitations, the short adoption cycle and receptive attitude of new technologies make ultra-capacitor entrants ideal partners to target in an early go to market strategy.

Once the market needs and target customers were identified the team targeted technical work to meet customers’ demands. Eonix developed a process for manufacturing and testing prototypes. Ultra-capacitor manufacturers need data on performance measures such as voltage stability, longevity, and resistance before testing a potential new electrolyte. Eonix develop new test ultra-capacitors that would be able to endure the prototype testing process.  In addition, the team needed to determine how the final electrolyte product could be manufactured on the large scale before bringing the technology to market. The team identified and engaged multiple chemical manufacturers that could potentially supply high grade electrolyte salts and solvents that would enable the production of batch electrolyte samples representative of a commercial product. After comparing the suppliers, a partner was identified that could produce electrolyte salts of high quality at a competitive price.  Prototype testing showed that Eonix’ pro...
